Consuming foods with pesticide residues can lead to a range of potential health effects on humans. These effects vary depending on the type and amount of pesticide residue present in food. Short-term (acute) exposure to high levels of pesticides can cause immediate health issues such as nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, and abdominal pain. It can also lead to more severe symptoms including dizziness, headaches, muscle weakness, and, in extreme cases, can affect the nervous system leading to seizures or loss of consciousness.

Long-term (chronic) exposure to lower levels of pesticides, even if they don't cause immediate symptoms, has been linked to more serious health conditions. This includes an increased risk of cancer, particularly cancers associated with the digestive tract, lungs, and lymphatic system. Pesticide exposure can also affect the endocrine system, leading to hormonal imbalances that can impact reproduction and development. There are also concerns about the impact on the immune system, potentially increasing the risk of infections and affecting the body's ability to fight them.

Children and pregnant women are particularly vulnerable to the effects of pesticides because of their developing bodies and brains. In children, exposure can contribute to developmental delays and cognitive impairments, as well as an increased risk of behavioral problems.

It's important to note that the risk associated with consuming pesticide residues on foods varies based on several factors including the type of pesticide, the amount consumed, and the duration of exposure. Regulatory agencies in many countries set limits on pesticide residues in foods to levels that are considered safe for human consumption. However, reducing exposure to pesticide residues by choosing organic foods when possible, washing fruits and vegetables thoroughly, and peeling them when appropriate can help mitigate potential health risks.
